esmModelGrid.description:
The grid utilised by the global UM atmosphere model is based upon a combination of the Arakawa C-grid for horizontal coordinates and the Charnley-Phillips grid for vertical coordinates. Together they define a set of staggered grid locations (nodes) in the horizontal and vertical planes. Grid positions are defined by spherical polar coordinates; that is, (lon,lat,r) where r represents a hybrid parameterised, terrain-following vertical coordinate. Within this framework the grid positions of the four primary model variables, P, u, v, w, are referenced as follows:
P = (i-0.5, j-0.5, k-0.5) u = (i, j-0.5, k-0.5) v = (i-0.5, j, k-0.5) w = (i-0.5, j-0.5, k)
where i, j and k represent whole-integral planes in model space, and i-0.5, j-0.5 and k-0.5 represent half-integral planes. Index coordinates (i,j,k) correspond to physical coordinates (lon,lat,r). The UM N48 grid is based upon a spherical Earth with radius 6371229.0 m.

gridTile.description: Salient facts concerning use of the Arakawa C-grid: - Array indexing in the latitude direction starts at the south pole. - For an unrotated grid mesh, longitude(i=0.5) == Greenwich meridian. - In the UM, the north and south poles coincide with the bounding half-integer j planes, i.e. j = 0.5 and j = M-0.5. - P-points and u-points exist at the poles, but not v-points. - At the poles all values of P are set equal. Likewise for scalar variables rho, theta, m, w.
